channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-3284] Big Pdf parsing to text - Out of memory
item.description:
I'm trying to parse a quite big PDF (26MB) and transform it to text, however I'm facing a huge memory consumption leading to out of memory error. Running my test with -Xmx768M will always fail. I've to increase to 1500M to make it work.
The resulting text is only 3MB so I don't understand why it is taking so much memory.

I've tested this code over 1.8.10, 1.8.11 & 2.0.0 with same result.

The pdf can be found here

My code:

Test.java
@Test
public void testParsePdf_Content_Memory() throws Exception {
{
    InputStream inputStream = new FileInputStream("c:/tmp/sr2015_mx_clearing_3dot0_mdr2_solution.pdf");
    try {
             StringWriter writer = new StringWriter();
	     FileWriter fileWriter = new FileWriter(new File("c:/tmp/test.txt"));

             PDFTextStripper pdfTextStripper = new PDFTextStripper();
	     pdfTextStripper.writeText(PDDocument.load(inputStream), fileWriter);

             fileWriter.close();
    } finally {
        inputStream.close();
    }
}
item.summary: Big Pdf parsing to text - Out of memory

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: PDFBox doesn't parse on demand. Thus many structures that aren't needed are parsed and expanded and do exist in memory, e.g. the many annotations (links) in the file. We've had complains about more memory usage than your complaint Btw you can save a little bit of memory by using FIle instead of stream, and by using a scratch file.

Thanks for your quick reply,
I tried to use a scratch file using:

RandomAccessFile randomAccessFile = new RandomAccessFile(new File("c:/tmp/pdf.tmp"), "rw");
pdfTextStripper.writeText(PDDocument.load(new File("c:/tmp/sr2015_mx_clearing_3dot0_mdr2_solution.pdf"), randomAccessFile), fileWriter);

But it still uses around 1 GB of memory (+ 280MB on disk now) . I can understand that the current behaviour of PDFBox is to read all the contents but I think it limits its usability.
Maybe having a way to extract only text or to select the desired elements could be a good solution.

Actually I am using Tika in front of PDFBox, so this issue also impact it.

First of all -Xmx768M isn't that much memory. I'd recommend 1-2GB. I've parsed 100MB+ PDFs with PDFBox with this amount of memory. As Tilman says, often memory usage is due to how you're opening files, and sometimes its due to a particular PDF (e.g. a file which includes a single giant image). Remember that while the compressed PDF file may only be 23MB PDFBox has to handle its uncompressed contents, parse that into various data structures, and load all the fonts from disk and parse them into various memory structures too, which can start using up quite a bit of memory.

Personally I've had the best results using a 32-bit JVM and opening the PDF directly from a File with no scratch file. Feel free to upload the problem PDF and we can see if there's something specific about that file which is causing the problem.
He did link to it. What I'd suspect is that it happens because 1) there are many objects including many that are not needed (annotations), and 2) all content streams are decompressed.

Commit 1736709 from tboehme in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1736709 ]

PDFBOX-3284: reduce memory footprint of COSDictionary by using a memory efficient Map implementation

Commit 1736710 from tboehme in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1736710 ]

PDFBOX-3284: disable debug statistic creation in COSDictionary

While doing a memory profiling on the provided PDF I found that a huge number of COSDictionary objects are created (more than 1 Mill.) while more than 90% only contain 2 or 3 items. After adding an instance logging I get the following figures for COSDictionary instances per item count:

9, 887416, 77608, 136, 879, 7332, 61326, 106, 805, 2534, 1, 8

(9 instances with 1 item , 887,416 with 2 items etc.).
Thus the used LinkedHashMap in COSDictionary is far away from being memory efficient for this case.
In order to resolve this in revision 1736709 I've added a 

o.a.p.util.SmallMap

implementation which is memory optimized for maps with few entries (smallest footprint I can think of) and used this instead of the LinkedHashMap in COSDictionary.
As a result text extraction of the PDF in question is down from a minimum of 1.4GB of heap space to 1.2 and even 1.1 (more garbage collection) thus the new map saves approx. 250MB heap space - and it is even a bit faster (3 seconds).
While there may be other parts which should also be memory optimized this should be a good start.
In the current version I've kept the code for getting the COSDictionary instance count in this class (enable it by changing boolean DO_DEBUG_INSTANCE_COUNT to true). It would be good to check other PDFs in regard to the item count distribution in COSDictionary. If we find examples with large number of items we may have to change the map implementation after reaching a certain item count for performance reasons.
Here's a statistic running preflight on about the 5000 first pdf files of the digitalcorpora site.

Commit 1736772 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1736772 ]

PDFBOX-3284: show index of biggest

Btw I also tried something, although it didn't work maybe I should mention it anyway - COSFloat stores a valueAsString, which isn't needed except for toString() and for writePDF, i.e. saving. However it made no difference for THAT file.

Thanks for the statistic. I would say that the assumption of 95-99% only very small COSDictionaries hold. It would be interesting if the processing time for documents with multiple dictionaries with above 100 entries degrades - I would assume not since creating the dictionaries is negligible compared to the other operations; only the O(n) look-ups may take a while. However we could also change the map implementation if number of entries exceeds a certain limit (e.g. >50).

I assume the string value in COSFloat was meant to keep the original value when writing a new PDF without precision changes. At least one may only store it if needed.

However I see another source for high memory consumption: the pure number of objects. With the PDF in question there are approx. 5 Mill. This results in some very large hash maps with large number of entries (e.g. for logging references). As I see it one could nearly half the number of objects when storing COSObject in the COSDocument objectPool. Currently the key is COSObjectKey and value COSObject. However object-number and generation-number of COSObjectKey is also available in COSObject. Thus it should be possible to store the same COSObject as key and value. What do you think?

I assume the string value in COSFloat was meant to keep the original value when writing a new PDF without precision changes. At least one may only store it if needed.

Now that you mention it, I think there was an issue about just that, i.e. avoiding some weird java floating point arithmetic effects.

I don't have an opinion about the other item you mention... I haven't looked into these parts deep enough

Thanks for the investigations.

I think it it good to try to reduce the memory footprint of parsing the whole document but I really think pdfbox should have a way to parse the document page per page for instance (and so having only a part of the document in memory). Having such a feature will ensure any pdf could be parsed, whatever how big it is.

Fyi, I tried to parse the same pdf using Itext. I can get the text with less than 200MB:

		PdfReader reader = new PdfReader(new RandomAccessFileOrArray(new RandomAccessSourceFactory().createSource(inputStream)), null);

		try {
			for (int page = 1; page <= reader.getNumberOfPages(); page++) {
				textWriter.write(PdfTextExtractor.getTextFromPage(reader, page));
			}
		} finally {
			reader.close();
		}

Rgds,
in jdk9, 2.0.6 needs 1020m to work and 3.0.0 needs 860m to work from the command line (ExtractText).
is this fixed?
No (there is no parse on demand). However 1020m to work isn't unusual.
Parse on demand is now available in PDFBOX-4569 thanks to Andreas.
Setting this one to resolved, the smallmap change hasn't made any troubles and works fine, and the parse on demand topic is in the other issue.

Commit 1865489 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1865489 ]

PDFBOX-3284: remove commented code and debug stuff, no longer needed
